name: Calibrachoa
climate: Calibrachoa thrives in temperate climates where the temperatures are not extremely hot or cold.
It is best suited for growing in regions with mild weather, avoiding harsh winters or hot, dry summers.
Calibrachoa can handle cooler summer climates, making it suitable for northern or coastal areas.
This plant prefers climates where humidity is moderate, promoting healthy growth and blooms.
sunlight: Calibrachoa requires full sunlight to partial shade for optimal blooming and growth.
Providing six to eight hours of direct sunlight helps the plant produce vibrant flowers.
If grown in areas with extremely hot sun, some afternoon shade may be beneficial.
Insufficient sunlight may lead to fewer blooms and leggy plant growth, reducing its aesthetics.
watering: Calibrachoa prefers consistently moist soil but does not tolerate waterlogged conditions.
Regular watering is necessary, particularly during the hot summer months to prevent wilting.
Ensure the container has drainage to allow excess water to escape, preventing root rot.
Reduce watering in cooler months and allow the soil to slightly dry out between waterings.
soil: Calibrachoa thrives in well-draining soil rich in organic matter to support healthy root growth.
A potting mix designed for container plants, with peat and perlite, works well for this plant.
The soil pH should be slightly acidic to neutral, ideally ranging between 5.5 and 6.5.
To improve drainage, amend garden soil with sand or use raised beds for planting Calibrachoa.
extra_care_tip: Pinch back the stems to promote bushier growth and more abundant blooms throughout the season.
Fertilize regularly with a balanced, water-soluble fertilizer to maintain plant vigor and flower production.
